A distinguished-looking government official speaks into t phone with a sense of subdued urgency.
I want to speak to the President. (listens for a moment) I'm sorry -- you'll have to interrupt  him.

A nationally known news commentator -- for purposes of th script let's say Drew Pearson -- is seated before a radio mike. He is also being photographed by TV cameras. In a w near him is a TV screen which shows what is going out on air. During the ensuing speech, a man comes in a hands hi sheaf of news bulletins.

Good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen,  this is Drew Pearson. We bring you  this special radio-television  broadcast to give you the latest  information on the landing of the  "space ship" in Washington.

Government and Defense Department  officials are concerned by reports  of panic in several large Eastern  cities. I am authorized to assure  you that so far there is no reasonable  cause for alarm. The rumors of  invading armies and mass destruction  are based on hysteria and are  absolutely false. I repeat -- these  rumors are absolutely false!

The ship, designed for travel outside  the earth's atmosphere, landed in  Washington today at 3:47 p.m., Eastern  Standard Time. We still don't know  where it came from, but I can reveal  that military leaders are considering  two possibilities; that it came from  some unfriendly power here on earth --  or that it actually arrived from  another planet.
CAMERA PANS to and DOLLIES IN on the TV screen in the wal On the screen is a shot of the space ship.
(over scene) The ship is resting exactly where it  landed two hours ago, and there has  been no sign of life from inside it.
OUR CAMERAL HOLDS on the TV screen. The cuts that follow inside the frame of the screen:
Two platoons of infantry soldiers surround the ship, thei rifles at the ready.
(over scene) Troops have been rushed from Fort  Myer and they have formed a cordon  around the ship.
showing two machine guns, two Sherman tanks and two 75MM  guns. The gun crews are posted for action and all weapons are trained on the space ship.

(over scene) As you can see for yourself, the  Army has taken every precaution to  meet whatever the situation may  require. Every eye -- every weapon --  is trained on the ship. It's been  this way for two hours and the tension--
as he interrupts himself excitedly, his attention riveted the TV screen.
Just a minute, ladies and gentlemen!  I think I see something moving!

We are at the actual location now, not looking at TV. We the ship surrounded by soldiers, two medium tanks, two  artillery pieces, and a couple of machine guns. As it does so, see a couple of metal objects rising slowly from the top the ship. One, which is an oddly-designed coil of wire, s up and revolves slowly. on the soldiers, their eyes glued to this first sign of  activity from the ship. They shift uneasily, gripping the rifles more firmly.

After a long, tense moment, a ramp appears silently out o the side of the ship and slides down to the ground. There an audible gasp as a man appears at the top of the ramp. looks around at the crowd with cool and imperturbable dig This is KLAATU. He is completely human in appearance. The only unearthly thing about him is his clothing. He wears tunic that is very good looking, but at the same time  thoroughly comfortable and practical. On his head is a me helmet that obscures most of his face. (It would be impos to identify him later.) The design of this helmet gives t impression that it is more a formal headdress than for  protection. Klaatu is above all an impressive man -- a ma of tremendous dignity and presence. He has the tolerant  superiority that comes with absolute knowledge.
of soldiers, people in the crowd, and policemen. The news and TV men are busy at their cameras.
After an impressive moment, he raises his arms in the  universal gesture of neutrality. Then he speaks, in perfe English, his voice amplified as though through an enuncia
We have come to visit you in peace --  and with good will.

Klaatu walks slowly down the ramp toward the soldiers. As does so, he draws from inside his tunic a strange looking object, longish and tubular. It might be a a telescope -- it might be some strange kind of weapon.

shooting from the side, showing Klaatu advancing slowly t the line of soldiers. He holds out the mysterious object front of him in a gesture that is actually one of offerin but could be misinterpreted as menacing. There is a growi uneasy rumble of muttering among the soldiers as Klaatu  advances. They are clearly frightened of what he may do.
A young second lieutenant, standing in front of his plato As Klaatu advances, the lieutenant unslings his carbine.

Klaatu starts toward the platoon leader, raising the obje he holds toward the man, trying to make clear his intenti Misinterpreting this as a menacing gesture, the platoon l raises his carbine to his shoulder.

of one of the tank commanders in the turret of his tank. is watching Klaatu advancing toward the platoon leader an he has drawn his pistol. Convinced that the lieutenant is jeopardy, the tank commander aims at Klaatu and fires.

as Klaatu falls to the ground wounded. The object he was  holding has dropped from his hand and smashed. The soldie start to gather around Klaatu excitedly when suddenly the appears in the entrance to the space ship a huge robot. T is a gasp of amazement from the crowd and the solders dra back at sight of him. The robot is ten feet tall, is made the almost-perfect image of a man. He is to be played by actor and his flesh appears to be made of a greenish meta His eyes flash as though lighted internally. His perfectl fashioned, muscular body is covered only with a loincloth This is GORT. There are cries of amazement as Gort walks slowly pondero down the ramp to the ground. As he does so, the ramp clos behind him. Gort's face is, and always remains, utterly  expressionless. He stops to look at Klaatu, lying on the  ground. Then he looks around at the soldiers, the tanks a guns. All the guns have been traversing to follow him.
From inside him there comes an ominous crackling sound, a though power were being generated within him. His eyes fl toward the tank from which Klaatu was shot.

There is a great metallic clatter and the Sherman tank is suddenly reduced to a pile of junk metal, its parts compl disintegrated. Only a piece of tank track and twisted gun barrel emerge from the heap on the ground to identify wha had been there. The tank's crew has remained unharmed.
The crackling sound continues as his eyes start to sweep a semicircle taking in all the troops.

as they react to the full shock of what has happened. Mos of them stand rooted to the ground. Several laugh  hysterically. A few break and run wildly.
Sudden pandemonium breaks out. Utterly terrified by what  they have witnessed, the crowd becomes a wild, milling,  screaming mob, concerned only with escape.

He has raised himself to a sitting position on the ground his wounded shoulder giving him considerable pain. The tw platoon leaders come into scene hesitantly, badly shaken the awesome demonstration of power they have seen. They a uncertain as to what they should do. The platoon leader e the smashed object on the ground curiously and turns  questioningly to Klaatu. With great dignity, Klaatu picks the broken object, which we see well for the first time. is a delicately-made tubular telescope, badly smashed. On are indications of small electronic gadgets.
It was a gift. For your President. (glances at the broken  object ruefully) With this he could have studied life  on other planets.

Klaatu lets the object drop with a shrug of mild exaspera The two lieutenants exchange a helpless look of bewilderm Then Klaatu raises himself to his feet painfully, holding his wounded shoulder. As he does so, a colonel and a capt come into scene.
(to the lieutenants) Is he all right?
Got hit in the shoulder, sir.
The three junior officers exchange ineffectual glances an look to the colonel, who thinks for a moment before makin his decision.
Send for an ambulance. Get him to  Walter Reed Hospital right away.
Yes, sir.

There is a door to the corridor and a door to Klaatu's ro In the small sitting room, talking in tones of hushed con is a group of men. There's a Major General, a likable man with a chest full of ribbons. There are also a Colonel in command of the hospital, a high-ranking police officer, a couple of medical officers and two civilians. The convers is interrupted by the entrance from Klaatu's room of a Me Corps Major, followed by an Army Nurse.
(to Major) How is he?
He's all right, General... Blood  pressure's a little high, but it  could be aggravation.
(wryly) Can't blame him. I always get mad  when somebody shoots me.
He still wants to see the President.
(to General) We informed the White House over an  hour ago.
(to Major) Didn't drop any hints about where  he's from, did he?
No, sir, he didn't.
The door to the corridor opens and a worried young Captai enters.
Excuse me. (to the Colonel) What about the reporters, Colonel?  They're swarming all over the lobby.
The Colonel turns, in deference, to the General.
(quietly) Tell them there won't be any statement  tonight.
Yes, sir. (glancing down the  corridor) Mr. Harley's here from the White  House.

Harley appears in the doorway, a brief case under his arm He's a dignified, intelligent member of the White House  secretariat. He proceeds uninterruptedly into the room,  nodding cordially to the General.
General --
(indicating Klaatu's  room) Right in there, Mr. Harley.
Harley proceeds in businesslike fashion to the door. He k and then enters.

as Harley enters, closing the door behind him. Klaatu no  longer wears his helmet and we see his face clearly for t first time. Even sitting up in bed, with his shoulder str in bandages, he is a figure of great authority. His face  reflects inner dignity and assurance. Harley, who is a  hardened diplomatist, can't help being impressed by his  present assignment and a little awed by Klaatu. Harley  obviously has been sent by the President to find out what can. Klaatu's eyes study him, cool, penetrating, reserved
My name is Harley -- Secretary to  the President (Klaatu continues to  study him silently) I've been told that you speak our  language -- that your name is Mr.  Klaatu.
(coolly) Just Klaatu.
The President asked me to convey his  deepest apologies for what has  happened. We all feel--
(evenly) Sit down, Mr. Harley.
Somewhat relieved, Harley seats himself. He speaks with a half smile, hoping to ease the tension.
I'm sure I don't have to point out  that your arrival was something of a  surprise. (getting a little  smile from Klaatu,  he is encouraged to  do some fishing) Had you been traveling long?
About five months -- your months.
You must have come a long way.
About 250 million of your miles.
Harley glances at him quickly to be sure he's not joking. He's not.
Naturally we're very curious to know  where it is you come from.
(easily; he's a  diplomat, too) From another planet. Let's just say  that we're neighbors.
Harley reacts, as his wildest assumptions are so blandly  corroborated.
It's rather difficult for us to think  of another planet as a neighbor.
I'm afraid, in the present situation  you'll have to learn to think that  way.
(eyebrows raised) The present situation?
I mean the reasons for my coming  here.
(his eagerness apparent) We're very curious about that, too.  Would you care to talk about it?
I'd be glad to. (noticing that Harley  is settling himself  expectantly) Not now, of course -- with you alone.
Perhaps you'd rather discuss it  personally with the President--
(somewhat sharply) This is not a personal matter, Mr.  Harley. It concerns all the people  on your planet.
(Startled by the scope  of this statement) I -- I'm not sure I understand--
I want to meet with representatives  from all the nations of the Earth.

(shocked and perturbed  by this notion) I'm afraid that would be a little  awkward. It's -- it's completely  without precedent. And there are  practical considerations -- the time  involved -- the enormous distances.
(coolly) I traveled 250 million miles. What  about your United Nations?
(Surprised and a little  puzzled) You know about the United Nations?
We've been monitoring your radio  broadcasts for a good many years.  That's how we learned your languages.  Lately, we've been getting your  television also.
(wryly) You must have a rather strange  impression of us.
(smiling) The first two years of television we  were convinced that all you did was  wrestle.
Harley smiles. Then his mind reverts to the seriousness o the situation and he speaks gravely.
I'm sure you recognize from our broad- casts the evil forces that have  produced the tension in our world.  Surely you would agree--
(evenly) I am not concerned, Mr. Harley, with  the internal affairs of your planet.  I consider that to be your business --  not mine.
I was only hoping to make you  understand.
(sternly, impressively) My mission here is not to solve your  petty squabbles. It concerns the  existence of every last creature who  lives on Earth.
(uncomfortably) Perhaps if you could explain a little--
I intend to explain. To all the  nations -- simultaneously. (his manner precludes  opposition) How do we proceed, Mr. Harley?
Harley is thoroughly shaken. The tremendous force and pow implicit in Klaatus's manner preclude the possibility of  argument.
(after a long  thoughtful moment) We could call a special meeting of  the General Assembly... But of course  the UN doesn't represent all of the  nations.
Then why not a meeting of all the  Chiefs of State?
(helplessly, but  patiently) Believe me, you don't understand.  They wouldn't sit down at the same  table.
Growing a little impatient with such nonsense, Klaatu eye him evenly, speaks with Jovian authority.
I don't want to resort to threats,  Mr. Harley. I simply tell you bluntly  that the future of your planet is at  stake... I suggest you transmit that  message to the nations of the Earth.
The eyes of the two men meet for a long, silent moment. T Harley rises quietly.
I will make that recommendation to  the President. (he picks up his brief  case and hat) I must tell you in all honesty that  I'm extremely dubious about the  results.
(with a half-smile) Apparently I'm not as cynical about  Earth's people as you are.
I've been dealing in Earth's politics  a good deal longer than you have. (he bows) Goodnight, sir.
He turns and goes out.
He stares after Harley for a moment, puzzled by this stra and apparently unreasoning world he has come to. He shake his head in thoughtful, tolerant bewilderment.
Searchlights have lighted up up the eerie shapes of the s ship and Gort. A circle of soldiers guard the area, while crew of men can be seen working around the ship.

A Master Sergeant of Engineers, dressed in fatigues, is  inspecting the side of the ship carefully. He has an acet torch in his had and a welding helmet over his face. The  Major General, previously seen in the hospital sitting ro enters and speaks to the Sergeant.
Getting any place, Sergeant?
(raising his helmet) No, sir. (shaking his head in  annoyance) Beats me, General. I saw that ramp  come out of the side of the ship --  right here. Now I can't even find a  crack!
A man named Carlson, a civilian metallurgical expert, com into scene. The General nods to him.
What's the report, Carlson?
(discouraged) We've tried everything from a  blowtorch to a diamond drill.
(nodding toward Gort) What about him?
He's made out of the same stuff.
Has he moved?
No sir. Not an inch
This is the toughest material I ever  saw, General. For hardness and  strength, it's out of this world.
(with a wry half-smile) I can tell you officially - that's  where it came from.
The two men exchange an uneasy glance, then turn to look the ship.
Two Medical Corps officers, a Captain and a Major are  interestedly studying a series of X-ray films.
The skeletal structure is completely  normal. (pointing) Same for the major organs - heart,  liver, spleen, kidneys.
And the lungs are the same as ours.  Must mean a similar atmosphere --  similar pressure. (nodding, toward  Klaatu's room) How old do you think he is?
Oh, I'd say forty-five.
(smiling) He told me this morning when I  examined him. He's seventy-eight.
I don't believe it.
Their life expectancy is a hundred  and thirty.
How does he explain that?
He says their medicine is that much  more advanced. (the major stares at  him blankly) He was very nice about it. But he  made me feel like a third-class witch  doctor.

The door to Klaatu's rooms opens and Major White appears. He's the man who attended Klaatu the day before. He close the door behind him and stands motionless facing the othe two, his face wearing a blank expression.
I took a bullet out of that man's  arm yesterday.
What about it?
(utterly bewildered) I just examined the wound and it's  all healed.
What does he say about it?
Said he put some salve on it -- some  stuff he had with him. (shows them a small,  odd-looking tube in  his hand)
What are you going to do with it?
Take it downstairs and have it  analyzed. (on his way to the  door, shaking his  head) Then I don't know whether I'll just  get drunk or give up the practice of  medicine.
As he starts out the door to the corridor, he passes Mr.  Harley, who is on his way in, carrying his ever-present b case. Harley is accompanied by an enlisted M.P.
Afternoon, Mr. Harley.
Afternoon, gentlemen.
Harley goes to the door of Klaatu's room, a businesslike  expression on his face. He knocks on the door, then enter The M.P. remains in the sitting room.
as Harley enters. Klaatu is up out of bed, walking around a Medical Corps robe and pajamas. He appears to be comple recovered.
Good afternoon. (surprised not to  find him in bed) I'm glad to see you up and around.
Thank you... Have you any news?

Not very good news, I'm afraid. (digs into his  briefcase for some  papers) The President accepted your suggestion  and cabled the invitations for a  meeting last night. (grimly) Let me read you some of the replies. (he selects a cable  and reads) "The Premier wishes to inform the  Government of the United States that  it will be impossible for him to  attend the meeting suggested by the  President unless the meeting is held  in Moscow." (with a grimly-pointed  glance at Klaatu,  Harley reads another  cable) "The suggestion of the President  regarding the possibility of a meeting  in Moscow would be unacceptable to  Her Majesty's Government at the  present time. Representation could  be sent only if the meeting were  held in Washington." (he looks up at Klaatu  and shrugs) Well -- there you have it.

Harley extends a sheaf of cables for Klaatu's inspection, but he ignores them. Klaatu has listened to this recital, first incredulously, then with mounting indignation. Cons of his quiet, Olympian wrath, Harley continues uncomforta
I tried to make you understand. The  suspicions -- the jealousies -- the  mistrust-- (uneasily, under  Klaatu's level gaze) Surely you realize that my government  has done everything in its power--
It's not your government I'm thinking  about. It's your world.
Now that you understand the situation  more clearly, perhaps you'd like to  discuss the matter with the President
(sternly) I will not speak to any one nation  or group of nations. (sharply, bitterly) I don't intend to add my contribution  to your childish jealousies and  suspicions.
Our problems are very complex, Mr.  Klaatu. You mustn't judge us too  harshly.
I can judge only by what I see.
Your impatience is quite  understandable.
(sharply) I am impatient with stupidity. My  people have learned to live without  it.
(ruefully) I'm afraid my people haven't. (with real sincerity) I'm very sorry -- I wish it were  otherwise.
Reluctantly Harley has picked up his hat and brief case. finds Klaatu staring out the window.
As he looks out the window thoughtfully. What he sees has given him an idea.
shooting down, from Klaatu's viewpoint, at people strolli about the hospital grounds. Most of them are civilian  visitors, but there is a sprinkling of nurses and ambulat patients.
As Klaatu turns back to Harley, he speaks thoughtfully,  incisively.
Before making any decisions, I think  I should get out among your people --  become familiar with the basis for  these strange, unreasoning attitudes.
Under the circumstances I'm afraid  that will be impossible.
Harley has paused near the door, a little embarrassed by  Klaatu's level gaze.
I must ask that you don't attempt to  leave the hospital. Our military  people have insisted on this. I'm  sure you'll understand.
With a polite nod, he goes out. Klaatu stares after him a he realizes that he is in effect a prisoner. He shakes hi head slowly, thoughtfully. The ways of this planet are st indeed.
Harley has paused to watch as the M.P. takes out a key an inserts it in the lock of Klaatu's door.
As he hears the click of the lock, he turns toward the do Realizing they've locked him in, he smiles with tolerant  amusement.

He exchanges a glance with the nurse, then pulls the door open and hurries inside.

CAMERA is on the back of a man dressed in a business suit who is walking along the sidewalk of a dimly lighted, alm deserted, middle-class street. He carries a suitcase and glances idly at the drab-looking stone facades of the old two-story houses. As he passes, from the open windows of houses come the voices of radio announcers. We get a sent or two from one house and then, as the man and our CAMERA pass on, this voice fades and another is picked up. We ge the impression that everyone is glued to his radio.
(over scene) --authorities at Walter Reed Hospital  refused to comment on how he managed  to escape, or what measures might be  taken to apprehend him.

--these fantastic descriptions of the creature are denoun as rumor by police Chief Walter Baxter. He is not eight f tall, as reported -- nor does he have tentacles in place arms-- --there's no denying that there is a monster at large --  that we are dealing with forces beyond our knowledge and  power. The public is urged to take ordinary precautions a to remain calm, as we await further developments-- --three separate reports of people who claim to have seen the "space man" in the past hour. One from Des Moines, Io one from a village in northern Florida; and one from Chic CAMERA OVERTAKES the man as he pauses under the light of street lamp, and reveals that it is Klaatu. He has stoppe to look at something out of scene.
from Klaatu's viewpoint, of a sign on one of the houses,  reading: ROOM FOR RENT

He seems to hesitate, debating a plan he has in mind. He  raises his right arm to scratch his head thoughtfully, an notices for the first time a small tag, or ticket, attach to the inside of the right forearm of the coat he is wear Puzzled, he pulls off the ticket and looks at it.

It is the sort of tag a cleaning establishment attaches t clothing. Printed on it is the legend: CAPITOL DRY CLEANI SERVICE. Scrawled in a penciled hand is the notation: Dr. Carpenter, Bldg. A - Walter Reed Hospital. Cl. & pr. $1.
He smiles wryly at this reminder of where he got the suit and he destroys the ticket. He glances down at the suitca beside him.
It bears the initials L.M.C. Klaatu's hand comes into sce and lifts up the suitcase. CAMERA HOLDS as Klaatu carries the bag toward the house and mounts the stone steps to th entrance.

There 's no light in the room except what splashes in fro the hall. Gathered around a television set are five adult and a little boy, their faces eerie in the reflected ligh from the screen. The room is done in average boardinghous style -- antimacassars and all. The attention of the peop is riveted on the television screen, where a newscaster i reading a bulletin.

--while the President made no effort  to minimize the crisis, he urged  people all over the country to remain  calm. He said the entire facilities  of FBI and other federal agencies  are being bought to bear. He pointed  out, however, that this is no ordinary  man hunt. He warned we may be up  against powers that are beyond our  control.
The landlady, a stern-faced woman of middle age, named MR CROCKETT, rises nervously and crosses to the television s
(tensely) I can't stand any more of this. It's  enough to drive a person crazy.
She snaps off the set sharply.

BOBBY BENSON, a bright-eyed, eleven-year-old, is seated b his mother, HELEN BENSON, an attractive girl of thirty.  Disappointed that the set has been turned off, Bobby's ro eye has fallen on something in the doorway to the hall... Wide-eyed, he nudges his mother and points.
Hey, Mom -- who's that?

including the doorway to the hall. Silhouetted motionless against the light from the hall is the figure of a man. A eyes follow Hobby's pointed finger, and there is a stifle gasp as they are startled out of their preoccupation. One the men turns on the lights and Klaatu is revealed standi calmly in the doorway. There is a shocked silence for a  moment, then Mrs. Crockett speaks.
(apologizing nervously  for the tension in  the room) I -- I'm sorry. What is it you want?
My name is Carpenter. I'm looking  for a room.
There is a noticeable letdown in the general tension, dur which Booby has been studying Klaatu, his imagination wor overtime.
Are you an FBI man?
No -- I'm afraid not.
Helen has stepped forward to make Bobby desist.
Bet he is, Mom. Bet he's out looking  for that space man.
(with an apologetic  smile at Klaatu) I think we've all been hearing too  much about "space men."
Mrs. Crockett reverts to her role as landlady. She likes think of her house as a home.

(starting the  introductions with  Helen) This is Mrs. Benson, Mr. Carpenter. (with a smile that  would split a brick) And little Bobby. (indicating a middle- aged couple and a  younger but more  wizened man) Mr. and Mrs. Barley -- and Mr.  Krull... I'm Mrs. Crockett.
There are polite noddings and how-do-you-do's. Mrs. Crock is satisfied that she's established a cozy atmosphere.
(pleased to the point  of challenge) Well -- this is our little family. (then, getting down  to business) I have a very nice room on the second  floor.
She leads the way toward the hall and Klaatu starts to fo picking up his suitcase, when he is intercepted by Bobby.
Can I help you look for the space  man? Can I? (excitedly) I know what he looks like! He's got  a square head -- and, three great  big eyes!
(good-naturedly,  calming him down) That's enough, Bobby. I think it's  time you went to bed.
(to Bobby, with a  prop smile) We mustn't annoy Mr. Carpenter -- or  he won't want to stay here. She goes  on into the hall, followed by Klaatu,  who has exchanged a polite smile  with Helen.
as Mrs. Crockett leads the way up the stairs.
He's really a dear little boy -- and  quiet as a mouse. (with a shrewd, chatty  smile) You're a long way from home, aren't  you, Mr. Carpenter?
How did you know?
(pleased with her  cleverness) Oh, I can tell a New England accent  a mile away.

Five of the boarders -- Mr. and Mrs. Barley, Mr. Krull, H Benson and Klaatu - are finishing their Sunday morning  breakfast. Mrs. Barley is a middle-class Helen Hokinson l form and unrelenting. Her husband is a born complainer. M Krull is a shriveled little accountant, precise and finic As they finish their coffee, all except Helen are immerse in the Sunday papers. Helen seems preoccupied with her ow thoughts. From a portable radio on the table comes Gabrie Heater's voice.

--and so, this Sunday morning, we  ask the question that's been plaguing;  the entire nation for two days now:  "Where is this creature and what is  he up to?" If he can build a space  ship that can fly to Earth -- and a  robot that can destroy our tanks and  guns -- what other terrors can he  unleash at will? ...Obviously we  must find this monster. We must track  him down like a wild animal and  destroy him.

head_text.subj: NEWSPAPER PAGE IN MRS. BARLEY'S HANDS

text: It is a full page layout, in the style of the American We showing a demented artist's conception of a mass invasion space ships. Weird-looking creatures are slaughtering Ear people with ray guns. The caption at the top of the image reads: "Are We Long For This World?" (Gabriel Heater's vo continues uninterruptedly over this and the next two scen
He is reading his paper with considerable interest.

The third-page story reads: SAVANT CALLS MEETING TO STUDY SPACE SHIP. Professor Jacob Barnhardt, world-famous scien and Nobel Prize winner, has invited fellow scientists fro all over the world to meet with him in Washington and stu the recently landed "Space Ship."
His face is thoughtful as he finishes reading. This story seems to impress and interest him. Then suddenly he finds his attention caught at what the Radio Voice is saying.
But where would such a creature hide  himself? Would he disappear into the  north woods? Or would he slither off  into the sewers of some great city?
Klaatu has a reaction of affronted dignity at this monstr distasteful idea.
There is grave danger -- everyone  agrees to that. The question is what  can we do to protect ourselves? What  measures can we take that will--
During the above, Mrs. Barley has turned to her husband i sharp annoyance.
George, I wish you'd turn that radio  off. I'm trying to concentrate.
Mr. Barley reaches out and snaps off the radio.
(snorting, he tosses  his paper down) Why doesn't the Government do  something -- that's what I want to  know.
(mildly) What can they do? They're only people --  Just like us.
People my foot! They're Democrats!
It's enough to give you the shakes.  He's got that robot standing there --  ten-foot tall -- just waiting for  orders to destroy us.
(thoughtfully) This space man -- or whatever he is.  We automatically assume he's a  menace... Maybe he isn't at all.
(glaring at her for  this silly notion) Then what's he hiding for? Why doesn't  he come out in the open?
Yeah. (indicating the radio) Like the fella says: "What's he up  to?"
Maybe he's afraid.
(with a derisive snort) He's afraid!
After all, he was shot the moment he  landed here. (she pauses for a  moment thoughtfully) I was just wondering what I would  do.
(to Helen, helpfully) Perhaps before deciding on a course  of action, you'd want to know more  about the people here -- to orient  yourself in a strange environment.
(sharply) There's nothing strange about  Washington, Mr. Carpenter.
(quietly, tongue in  cheek) A person from another planet might  disagree with you.
If you want my opinion, he came from  right here on Earth. (with significant  emphasis) And you know where I mean.
They wouldn't come in a space ship.  They'd come in airplanes.
(as though with  superior knowledge) I wouldn't be so sure about that.
(delivering the final  word) Stands to reason that fella wants  some thing or he wouldn't be here. (facing Klaatu) That make sense, Carpenter?
Klaatu pauses for a moment, then recites pleasantly.
I must admit I'm a little confused.
Mrs. Crockett enters and speaks to Helen.
Mrs. Benson -- Mr. Stevens is here  to see you.
Oh -- thank you.
She rises and goes out.
Finish your coffee, George. I told  the Carsons we'd be there at eleven.
as Helen crosses the room to greet TOM STEVENS. He's a  personable young man with a breezy manner and considerabl charm. There is between them an easy air of Intimacy.
(smiling warmly) Good morning.
Tom kisses her.
We're all set. I picked up some  sandwiches and put gas in the car.  And the radio's still busted, so me  can forget about the space man for  today.
(a little disturbed) There's only one thing -- I haven't  been able to arrange for anyone to  stay with Bobby. (tentatively) I don't suppose we could take him  with us?
(understandably  unenthusiastically) Well, we could--
There's always somebody here, but  today of course they've all got plans.
I haven't any plans.
Helen and Tom turn in surprise.
including Klaatu, who has wandered in from the dining roo unnoticed by Tom and Helen. Klaatu continues, with an air wanting to be helpful without wanting to interfere.
I'd be glad to spend the day with  him -- if you'd let me.
(impulsively) Say, that'll be great! Wouldn't it,  Helen.
(hesitating, a little  confused, by the  offer) It's awfully nice of you to suggest  it. (remembering the two  men haven't met) I'm sorry Mr. Carpenter -- this is  Tom Stevens.
The two men shake hand's and exchange how-do-you-do's. Th Klaatu turns back to Helen.
Bobby and I had a fine time yesterday  afternoon. We talked -- and listened  to the radio. (smiling at Helen) I thought today he might show me  around the city.
Helen is debating the matter in her mind, concerned about leaving Bobby with a comparative stranger, but tempted be of her favorable impression of Klaatu.
(easily) Suppose I ask Bobby how he feels  about it.
He turns, with a little smile, and starts out of the room Helen, still not quite decided, turns to Tom with a  questioning look. Tom nods.
The great seated, brooding figure of Lincoln is at the fa end of the impressive main hall. A few tourists are movin about the place.
They are in the south hall, on the wall of which is inscr the Gettysburg Address. They stand silently, side by side reading the inscription.
Featuring the last part of the Address. It reads: "--and  that government of the people, by the people, for the peo shall not perish from the earth."
(visibly impressed) Those are great words. (with an air of  discovery) He must have been a great man.

Bobby is impressed by the depth and sincerity of Klaatu's tribute, but a little confused by his air of having disco Lincoln. Hobby watches Klaatu with a puzzled expression,  then follows as Klaatu moves off slowly.
shooting against one of the huge fluted columns as Klaatu and Bobby come out of the building. Deeply preoccupied, K speaks with impatient urgency.
That's the kind of man I'd like to  talk to.
Bobby looks up at him in bewilderment. After a moment Kla speaks slowly, thoughtfully.
Bobby -- who's the greatest man in  America today?
(puzzling it over) Gee -- I don't know... The space  man, I guess.
(secretly amused) I was speaking of earth men. I meant  the greatest philosopher -- the  greatest thinker.
You mean the smartest man in the  whole world?
Yes -- that would do nicely.
(after a moments  thought) Well -- Professor Barnhardt, I guess.  He's the greatest scientist in the  world.
(he pauses  thoughtfully, speaks  slowly, as he recalls  the newspaper story  he read) He lives here in Washington, doesn't  he?
Sure. Right near where my mother  works.
Where is that?

Department of Commerce. She's a  secretary. (Klaatu nods) They have a man they call the  Secretary, but he isn't at all. My  mother's a real secretary. (after a moment;  eagerly) Mr. Carpenter -- now can we go see  the space ship?

A crew of Army engineers is in process of erecting a temp structure such as a large Quonset hut or B29 hanger to en the space ship and Gort. The walls are partially up and  already have concealed part of the ship. The area is rope off and there are Army guards to keep the sightseers back There is a crowd of people behind the ropes, watching. CA MOVES IN to reveal the backs of Bobby and Klaatu.
Bobby is studying the ship and Gort eagerly, his imaginat thoroughly aroused. Klaatu is watching the men at work wi mild, quiet amusement.
from Bobby's viewpoint.
Bobby's eyes are wide with awe as he watches the giant ro
Boy, I'll bet he's strong. I bet he  could knock down a whole building.
(with a quizzical  smile) I shouldn't be at all surprised.
Bobby's attention shifts to the ship.
From Bobby's viewpoint.
(excitedly, indicating  the ship) Gee, I'd like to get inside and see  how it works. What do you think makes  it go?
(quietly, after a  glance around) Well -- atomic power, I would imagine.
(looking at Klaatu  incredulously) I thought that was only for bombs.
No. It's for a lot of other things,  too.
You think it can go faster than an F- 36?
Yes -- I think so.

shooting from a side angle to include a couple of men who are listening to Klaatu's conversation. They are nudging  each other, amused at the way this man is pretending to  explain things to the little boy.
About a thousand miles an hour?
Klaatu has noticed the two men, who have edged a little c to listen. He is not perturbed by them, but he lowers his voice a bit.
Maybe four thousand miles an hour.  And outside the Earth's atmosphere a  good deal faster.
(excitedly) Gee! How could they make a landing?
Well -- there are several ways to  reduce landing speed. You see, the  velocity--

Klaatu interrupts himself as he realizes that he may be g too far. The two men have moved closer, listening and  grinning. One of them whispers to the other behind the ba of his hand. Then the man realizes that Klaatu has stoppe speaking and is looking at him.
(grinning) Keep goin', Mister. He was fallin'  for it.

The two men burst out laughing and move off together. Bob who has missed the point of this by-play, looks at Klaatu then after the men. As they move out of scene they laugh  loudly at the little boy's confusion. Klaatu takes Bobby' hand to lead him away from the roped-off area.

CAMERA FOLLOWS them as they move away through the crowd. As they do so, several newsboys are working their way thr the crowd with newly arrived extras. The boys are calling out the extras: "Police under fire!" "Army put in charge! "Space man still at large!" etc. People are eagerly buyin the papers. Klaatu and Booby watch this as they pass thro the crowd.
In newsboy's hand. The headline reads: SPACE MAN ELUDES P ARMY PUT IN CHARGE.
In another newsboy's hand. This headline reads: DISTRICT  UNDER MARTIAL LAW. CONGRESS ACTS AS POLICE CHIEF REIGNS.
as they move on away from the excited crowd of people.  Klaatu's reaction has been one of mild curiosity. Bobby l up at him.
You think they'll ever find him?
(alter a moment's  pause) I don't know, Bobby. I'm inclined to  doubt it.
(as they continue  walking) Mr. Carpenter -- what does velocity  mean?
(preoccupied) Velocity is the time rate of change  of position.
This explanation misses Bobby by several light years. He  glances up at Klaatu blankly.
I'll bet that's the way Professor  Barnhardt talks.
Pulled out of his reverie, Klaatu glances down at Bobby a smiles apologetically. Bobby grins back at him. Then, as  they walk on a few more steps, Klaatu stops and speaks  thoughtfully.
Bobby -- I have an idea. Let's go  see Professor Barnhardt and find out  how he talks.
(with a half-smile of  accusation) You're just kidding, aren't you?
Wouldn't you like to meet him?
Well, sure I would, but -- (he's to be not going  taken in) Aw, I'll bet you'd be scared.
(with a private smile) We can scare him more than he can  scare us.
Bobby stares up at him and his face breaks into a broad  admiring grin.
I like you, Mr. Carpenter. You're a  real screwball.

The house is an unimposing old-fashioned structure, shoul on either side by similar one-family dwellings. There is flight of stone steps leading up to the entrance and a la porch across the front of the house. Klaatu and Bobby wal into scene and pause, Klaatu glances at Bobby and Bobby n toward the house. They move on up the steps to the entran
Bobby, all eagerness and excitement, presses the bell. Th wait a moment and there is no answer.
(disappointed at the  thought) Gee -- maybe he isn't home.
Bobby wanders down the porch and looks into a window.  Fascinated by what he sees, he gestures to Klaatu.
Betcha this is where he works--
After a glance at the front door, Klaatu joins Bobby at t window and looks in.

SHOOTING through the window, over the heads of Klaatu and Bobby. The room is more of a workroom than a study. It is comfortably shabby disarray, with papers and books everyw There's a battered old desk and a day bed. One wall is so bookshelves and on the other two are blackboards covered  with a fantastic array of complex equations, graphs and  diagrams.
His attention has been caught by one of the blackboards a he studies it with great interest and curiosity.

It is covered with a particularly complicated series of  equations in a chalky scrawl, involving angles of vector, Keplerian ellipses, etc. The final equations are unsolved they have no answers after the "equals" sign. Across are  little printed signs tacked to the blackboard reading: "D erase!" and "Don't touch!"

Bewildered, Bobby looks from the blackboard up at Klaatu. Still studying the blackboard, Klaatu is shaking his head and clucking his tonsure as one might at the attempts of child to solve a problem in arithmetic.
(indicating the  equations) What does that mean?
It's a problem in celestial mechanics.
Bet he's the only one in the world  knows the answer.
(he shakes his head,  smiling) He doesn't know the answer. And he'll  never get it that way.

Bobby moves over to a pair of French doors beyond the win and tries to peer in through the curtained doors. He abse tries the doors and finds them locked. Then he turns away with a disappointed but philosophical shrug.
We probably couldn't get to see him  even if he was home.
As Bobby moves away from the doors dejectedly, Klaatu put his hand on the knob.
He's watching Klaatu and his eyes widen at what he sees.
(in complete surprise) Hey -- where you going?
He has opened the door and is standing in the doorway, hi hand, still on the knob. He is smiling at Bobby with secr amusement. He's got an idea.
If he's that difficult to see, perhaps  we ought to leave a calling card.
Klaatu disappears into the study. Amazed, Bobby follows.
Bobby watches as Klaatu walks to the blackboard and picks a piece of chalk. As though correcting a schoolboy's work he makes large check marks at several points in each equa

An efficient-looking middle-aged woman is mounting the st to the entrance, getting her front door key out of her pu when her eye falls on the French doors, which are standin ajar. Puzzled, she starts down the porch toward the doors This woman is Barnhardt's secretary and her name is HILDA Bobby is watching as Klaatu writes across the blackboard a bold hand: Differentiate the equation ( ). Klaatu underlines this comment with a sharp stroke, when stern voice is heard off screen.
What are you doing in here?
as Klaatu and Bobby turn in surprise. Standing in the ope French doors is Hilda, eyeing them with stern suspicion.

(outraged by Klaatu's  desecration of the  sacred blackboard) How dare you write on that blackboard! (Klaatu eyes her mildly) Do you realize the Professor has  been working on that problem for  weeks?
(pleasantly) He'll catch on to it in no time now.
(controlling herself  with an effort) How did you get in here? And what do  you want?
We came to see Professor Barnhardt.

Well, he's not here. And he won't be  back till this evening. (sternly) I think you'd better leave now.  Unruffled, Klaatu turns to the desk  and scribbles something on a scratch  pad. He tears off the piece of paper  and hands it to Hilda.
You might keep this. (with easy assurance) I think the professor will want to  get in touch with me.

With a polite nod he goes out the French doors, followed Bobby. Hilda eyes the door for a moment, then glances dow at the paper in her hand, disturbed and puzzled by this  stranger. Her glance wanders to the blackboard and she pi up an eraser, debating whether to erase Klaatu's correcti At that moment the French door opens and Klaatu sticks hi head in. Startled, Hilda drops the eraser.
(pointing to the  blackboard) I wouldn't erase that. The Professor  needs it very badly.
And he disappears, leaving Hilda to glare after him in  impotent rage. Deciding that this man is either a crackpo or a menace, she goes to the telephone on the desk and st dialing a number.

as Klaatu and Bobby come down the steps and turn into the sidewalk. They are talking and laughing together, but we  can't hear their conversation. CAMERA PANS with them as t move on up the sidewalk, revealing two kids playing hopsc Klaatu watches, fascinated, as he walks by. Then, having  passed the kids, he tries the one-footed, then two-footed hop that characterizes the game.
Hilda is talking on the phone.

--no, Sergeant, there was no  classified material around, but I  have instructions to report anything  unusual to the police... Yes -- I'm  Professor Barnhardt's secretary. (consulting the paper  in her hand) The man's name is Carpenter -- and  he lives at 1615 St. Street, N.W...  Yes, that's right--
Bobby and Klaatu come out of a wooded path into a section the cemetery where the myriad crosses seem to reach into  infinity. They pause for a moment, then Bobby leads the w through one of the rows.
in one of the many rows are crosses that extend beyond CA RANGE. CAMERA MOVES IN on one of the crosses. It bears th name LT. ROBERT BENSON.
as they come into scene and look down at the grave.
That's my father. (Klaatu glances at  the boy, then nods  understandingly) He was killed at a place called Anzio.
Klaatu's glance roves out thoughtfully to the infinite ro of crosses, and his eyes are sad as they return to Bobby.
Klaatu and Bobby are approaching a bench beside a pathway overhung with trees. Bobby leads the way to the bench and they sit down. Klaatu's eyes stray out to the myriad cros
(Reflectively) Did all these people die in wars?
(somewhat surprised) Sure. Didn't you ever hear of  Arlington Cemetery?
No -- I'm afraid not.
(very serious) Mr. Carpenter" -- you don't seem to  know about anything.
(Amused) I'll tell you, Bobby -- I've been  away for a long time. Very far away.
Is it different where you've been? (indicating the  cemetery) Don't they have places like this?
(slowly) They have cemeteries. But not like  this one... You see, they don't have  any wars.
Bobby looks at him, puzzled and impressed by this  incomprehensible notion.
Gee -- that's a good idea.
His eyes are drawn subconsciously out to the rows of cros Then he turns back to Klaatu with a slow-dawning look of  curiosity, and Klaatu deliberately changes the subject.
What would you like to do this  afternoon?
After a moment Bobby's expression changes and he breaks i a broad grin.
Go to the movies.
All right.
(he didn't dare hope  for this) No foolin'? Will you?
Certainly. (then he hesitates) Tell me, Bobby -- do you have to  have money to go there?
Bobby gives him a look of amazement, then grins, assuming Klaatu was kidding and simply hasn't any money.
(eagerly) I've got some money. My mother gave  me two dollars.
No -- I want to take you to the  movies. (he takes some objects  out of his pocket) Do you think they'd accept these?
Sparkling in his palm are eight or ten cut diamonds of va sizes.
The boy is staring at the stones in wide-eyed amazement.
Gee -- those look like diamonds!
Some places that's what people use  for money. They're easy to carry --  and they don't wear out.
(staring at them  fascinated) Bet they're worth about a million  dollars.
Would you give me your two dollars  for a couple of them?
(with a nervous, unsure  smile) Well, sure, but--
The boy studies Klaatu's face to see if he's kidding.  Realizing that he's not, Bobby's face takes on a childish shrewd expression -- as though he were about to trade a  jackknife for an ocean liner.
(slowly) Okay.

The boy takes out two dollar bills and offers them almost challengingly. Klaatu takes the bills and hands Bobby two good-sized Diamonds. They study their new acquisitions wi interest. Bobby looks up from his diamonds to steal a gui glance at Klaatu.
Let's not say anything to my mother  about this, Mr. Carpenter.
(mildly curious) Why not, Bobby?
(gravely) She doesn't like me to steal from  people.

Shooting toward the curb as a police prowl car drives up stops in front of the boardinghouse. A Detective in  plainclothes gets out and gestures to the uniformed Drive to pull up the street a way and wait. The Driver nods and the car moves off as the Detective crosses the sidewalk t the boardinghouse.

As the Detective mounts the steps he glances through a wi into the living room. Klaatu can be seen reading to Bobby who is perched happily on the arm of Klaatu's chair. The  Detective moves to the front door ant rings the bell. The is the sound of running feet and in a moment the door is  opened and Bobby appears.
Mr. Carpenter come home yet?
(studying the man  curiously) Yeah -- he's right inside.
Tell him I'd like to see him.
(calling out) Mr. Carpenter--! (to the Detective) Come on in.
The Detective steps inside and Bobby closes the door, as  Klaatu appears from the living room.
Your name Carpenter?
(puzzled that anyone  should know him) Yes. (then recalling, with  a smile of  satisfaction) Oh -- I suppose Professor Barnhardt's  looking far me.
(dryly, with grim  emphasis) I been looking for you all afternoon.
An inexpensive convertible -- a 1948 Ford, or Chevrolet - drives up and stops in front of the house. Helen and Tom in it.
You get the feeling that Helen and Ton have spent a very  enjoyable day together and are reluctant to say goodnight Tom puts his arm around her and kisses her.
(fondly) It was a wonderful day.
You still haven't answered my  question.
(warmly sincere) You know how I feel, Tom. I just  want to think it over.
The boss is leaving for Chicago  tomorrow. If I could tell him I was  getting married -- with two dependents--
(smiling) You're a good salesman -- but I've  got to think about it.
A good insurance salesman wouldn't  give you time to think.
With a smile and, a quick kiss, Helen gets out of the car
'Night.
as Helen turns and hurries across the sidewalk to the hou In the entrance she turns and waves to Tom. He waves back and drives off slowly. Helen lets herself in with her key

The Detective is putting on his hat and preparing to leav with Klaatu as Helen enters. There is a moment of awkward and confusion as she glances, puzzled, at the Detective.  Bobby runs to her and greets her excitedly.
Hi Mom!
Hello, darling. (she kisses Bobby,  then turns  questioningly to  Klaatu and the  Detective) Good evening, Mr. Carpenter.
Klaatu is uneasy but tries not to show it as he smiles in greeting and introduces the Detective.
Mrs. Benson -- this is Mr. Brady.
(Impressively) Mr. Brady's a cop.
Helen glances quickly at the Detective, then at Klaatu,  surprised and troubled. She turns to Bobby to cover her  confusion.
(to Bobby) Did you have a nice day, dear?
(enthusiastically) Boy, we had a swell time. Didn't we,  Mr. Carpenter?
We certainly did.
We went to the movies -- and we had  ice cream cones -- and we went to  see Daddy--
